div.p: good evening first thanks for having me
I appreciate it my name is faisal khan i
am the CEO and president of project 6
which is a 501c3 pending nonprofit
organization created and designed to
oversee and identify government
corruption primarily in chicago but
across Illinois I like to
institutionally members of my team who
have already kind of said hello my gram
is here Orlando Ortiz and Nate Hamilton
I am a former legislative inspector
general for the city of Chicago and if
you're not familiar with that title it
was only created about five years ago I
was the first legislative Inspector
General of the city of Chicago and my
job was directly to oversee City Council
and aldermen to make sure that they were
behaving not committing crimes staying
on the right side of the ethics code and
doing what they were supposed to do
unfortunately as you guys know if says
all of you follow Chicago politics 31
alderman before I showed up went to jail
in 30 years so Chicago unfortunately is
not known for its its good ethics
boundaries courtesy so when my term
ended his legislative inspector general
unfortunately ended in a bad way in that
not only did they decide not to continue
my contract but they decided to shut the
office down in general so the one and
only time there was oversight of City
Council it lasted four years and then it
was closed down project six was born out
of that void of the idea that they're no
longer was oversight here in Chicago of
its elected officials in any meaningful
way so I create a project six to
continue the work that we were doing at
the legislative inspector general's
office i'll refer to that as oleg moving
forward so basically in its in its
shortest form we're continuing to do
investigations we've gained some
handcuffs we've lost some handcuffs so
that's information that i'll go over
with you so you understand what I'm
talking about and this is a
talk to you for hours and hours about
this so cut me off at any time ask a
question do whatever you need so we can
get through this an investigation in it
simpler for simplest form is something
that you can all relate to its data sets
would you call it data sets we sometimes
call it data sets but it's evidence it's
in the form of physical evidence oral
evidence records anything that you can
think of that can help us identify the
problem that we're dealing with and the
solution that we need to get to and so
my role as chief investigator both at
the legislative inspector general's
office and now at project six along with
my team is to gather that information is
to gather the data set analyze the data
set and then present it to all of you or
two members of Chicago in a in a
cognizant way so everybody can
understand exactly what we did and so
like I said we've unfortunately gained
some handcuffs as a result of
transitioning from a government agency
to the private sector and lost some
handcuffs and so let me give you some
examples of that and a legislative
inspector general I had the authority of
a municipal agency behind me so when I
called people would listen they would do
as I asked I would be able to get people
to come in and talk to me when I needed
them to come talk to me so there was an
air that we carried that we simply no
longer have the other tool that we had
was obviously access to databases that
we don't have any more government
databases law enforcement databases
examples are accurate and clear that law
enforcement agencies used across the
country to be able to secure various
information so if I wanted to know your
social security number your driver's
license number the car that you drove
your known associates whether you ever
declared bankruptcy whether you've been
involved in litigation these are just
some of examples that I was able to
access through that information I can't
get that anymore but the biggest tool
that I lost was subpoena power and all
of you know what subpoena subpoena is I
don't need to go into the details of
that but subpoena power is incredibly
important because in my job most
investigations are historical so it's
not like there's an ongoing
crime right now or an alderman is taking
a briefcase full of money and I can get
there just to catch it when it happens
it's often chasing the money it's often
chasing the dollars finding the bank
records where the money is finding the
housing records finding whatever I can
from banks from organizations from
companies from city departments that
somehow don't want to provide us with
the information that we needed to issue
a subpoena so once we transition from a
government organization to a private
sector a not-for-profit we lost all of
those powers so what we did have what we
had to do was essentially pivot we
pivoted into now taking on different
sources of information and using them to
the best of our abilities and I think
I'll focus primarily I'm three that we
use to the best of our abilities and the
first one is open source internet which
is basically your search engines your
social media sites that you normally
would not look for information from but
you'd be surprised what you can find on
facebook on twitter on linkedin
information that you won't find
sometimes in a government database like
accurint we found connections between
people and their pictures in their
Facebook files we found statements that
they've made on their accounts that
completely contradict what they've told
us in the past or what they've made made
statements to the press and speaking of
the press the Tribune is sometimes or
any other media websites are incredibly
helpful to information gathering so we
have to really dig down into the open
source information it get as much out of
it as we can to collect that data and
put it together and supplement the work
that we already have hi we're not we are
still primarily focusing on doing
investigations so as legislative

p.span: inspector general I took complaints from

div.p: citizens of Chicago to talk about their
relationships their problems that they
had with elected officials here in
Chicago we're doing the same thing a
project sex whistleblowers people are
reaching out to us to provide us with
tips about what is going on they were
solicited for a bribe their know of
corruption in various departments their
scams being bulled by your elected
officials
they're lining their own pockets and not
doing what's in their best interest for
you but rather for them so I consider
ourselves solar direct investigative
agency but we are still using
journalistic tools to help us supplement
the information that we need to cover
for the information that we lost through
subpoena power if that answers your
question so we go through the open
source information and then we also go
back to government websites but these
are the ones that are similar to open
source information so we go directly to
city sites like cook county as the
gentleman was describing earlier and
seek information through through those
places whether we go to the registrar's
office the tax assessor's office the
comptroller's office because each
contains information that unfortunately
is not aggregated in one place and I'll
come back to that in a little bit but we
constantly now are going to different
sources to see if we can extract the
same information we might have got
sooner with a subpoena or other resource
but now have to go about it in this
manner but the strongest resource that
we have now as a non-for-profit as
project six is something that not only
do I use but all of you can use and
that's the power of FOIA I'm sure mostly
you're familiar with it before is the
Freedom of Information Act and it's a
tool that citizens have to get
information from their government
whether it's on a state level local
level federal level it's an ability for
you to request from an organized from a
government organization any information
you want there are grounds on which they
can deny that information but the
majority of time they can provide it to
you so we ask very specifically for very
specific information to supplement what
we're doing so for example we've asked
for spending records by elected
officials we've asked for tax records
for elected officials these are just
some examples what you can what you can
use it for and there really aren't too
many limitations we've looked at
personnel records from people to see
where they've been qualified for certain
things so so the topics go on and on
oftentimes foyers can be rejected and
the key to that is drafting FOIA is in a
very specific way in that there is no
leeway for an agency to
now your request so if I was telling you
how to draft a FOIA I will tell you if
there's information you are seeking be
as clear as possible about it and and
and make sure there's no wiggle room in
there and try to identify as much as you
can now one of the cons of that
obviously is that sometimes you don't
want to tip your hand as to what you're
looking for and what and you don't want
them to know exactly that you're on to
something so you may have to throw in an
extra foyer and kind of throw them off
the scent that way or sometimes be a
little more or general but these are the
kinds of investigative things that you
need to do in order to get the
information that you want and that's
what we've been doing a project six is
simply utilizing as much information as
we can and and I bring us back to the
data sets that I was talking about
because we have gone to various
different city agencies to secure
information and and i think this example
is particularly prevalent to the
problems that we face that I think you
will face if you are doing some of the
similar things that we are we about two
months ago we completed an investigation
here in the city of Chicago about
alderman taking illegal contributions
just in the year 2015 and as a result of
our study we identified that of 50
alderman of the 50 30 or seven of them
took illegal contributions and
aggregating over five hundred thousand
dollars just one year if you can imagine
for a local campaign donations were
given in excess of half a million
dollars which were illegal and I call
them illegal why because there are
strict limitations in place as to how
much money you can give to an elected
official here in Chicago if you fall in
certain categories if you're a lobbyist
if you're a vendor if you're a business
doing business with a city or if you're
seeking legislation from the city you
are subject to a strict cap of fifteen
hundred dollars over a calendar year now
there are ways to circumvent that role
as if you want to go see our report it's
available on our website at the secret
6.com people in fact use their their
colleagues and their friends to
supplement donations they use their
company names their DBAs their their
spouses you can think of any which way
to do it they do it and so for in order
for us to identify
these these individuals who violated the
law we had to go through not only one
database to databases but we're talking
about close to ten databases in order to
properly look at the information that we
needed let's start at the beginning in
order for an alderman to know who is
donated so an alderman you have to go to
the State Board of Elections website the
state board of elections in fact is a
proactive agency does not investigate on
its own it only investigates when a
complaint is filed so it also only
operates on the honor system so in
alderman when an alderman reports how
much money he received that's what
you'll see on the state aboard state
elections website we have no idea
whether that's accurate or not that's
only what they're willing to tell the
state that that's what they received so
if your alderman took an envelope full
of cash this morning and decided not to
report down as d2 which is a document
they use will never know that happened
so we only rely on actually what
alderman have reported in order to
determine what in fact was or was not
illegal so you can imagine that even of
the reported amounts we were able to
find over half a million dollars in one
year and and just so you know for
historical purposes this investigation
has not been done in Chicago for almost
ten years even though other agencies
have been tasked with this this topic
has been dead and buried for a little
bit and so we decided to resurrect it
because we felt that campaign finance is
very important as I'm sure you've all
seen in the news and on a state level on
a federal level and and other places so
we started with the state board of
elections website and we took the data
that was on that website and we noted
immediately the easy ways that people
cheat they misspelled names they use
different addresses even though they're
same person they changed their company
names they change spouses names so the
first thing we noticed was the weakness
in the site that we weren't able to
manipulate that data to see how we could
use it best to identify the problems
that we thought we regard to see so my
team first pulled off all that data off
the website and put it into our own
spreadsheet and started manipulating the
data there to sort it to see whose whose
clothes and names who's close in age
whose clothes in addresses to identify
any common patterns we could so the next
step after that is obviously we then
have to now identify the people and the
comp
is donating to these particular
individuals and so we had to go to
portal after portal and if any of you
have been to City portals before you'll
see that the city's portals are
incredibly scattered and fragmented what
the parks department has on their portal
is completely different to what the city
of Chicago has on their portal for
instance vendor payments are available
in the parks department's portal but
they're not available in the city of
Chicago's portal even though their
sister agencies it's one big city
there's no aggregation of this data so
we went to looking at the contracts list
on one place vendors listed in another
place lobbyists list in another place
and it goes on and on and on and so my
team for three straight months for eight
or ten hours a day had to physically
pull that data copy it line by line to
put it into an aggregate to put in a
spreadsheet aggravated so we could
manipulate it and identify all the
problems that we found and and and the
conclusion and the point I'm making is
that that simply was unnecessary if
we're seeking open and open government
and a transparent government these are
problems that we should not be having
today this information should be readily
available to me to any of you to be able
to find and be able to identify a
problem in and of itself we had
individuals review the work that we did
and they said they simply couldn't
duplicate it because it would take them
too long because there's no resource
available for them to compare it against
and that is something that simply in
this day and age in the city of Chicago
shouldn't be happening whether it's
happening intentionally to make life
hard so we can't see what your elected
officials are doing or whether it's just
done by pure and competence it shouldn't
be happening so we are obviously always
looking for ways to improve that system
and and to make this easier so when any
one of you want to go out and see what
your elected officials are doing how
they're spending your taxpayer dollars
what they're doing where the contracts
going where's the money going who's
bringing it in who's taking it you
simply should be able to do that without
spending four days on it and
unfortunately that's the problem that we
face here there's disadvantages to it
all of course I mean you know for the
all the pros of the foyers I've talked
about the cons you know the the work
that we did in campaign

div.p: time time now could we could have spent
somewhere else obviously but this is the
only way to get it done and until

that this concept of transparency is
paramount and priority it's not going to
change and so as an investigator my life
gets harder but it doesn't deter me any
less and trying to find the right answer
because when you do the the success
comes from knowing that we were able to
find out exactly how we were being
screwed in by who so thank you folks and
that's basically the message that I have
for you here is that investigations rely
on data and whether there are criminal
investigations as I was a former
prosecutor whether their administrative
investigations that I did as legislative
inspector general or whether they're
hybrid which is what we're doing at this

and the access to that information and
unfortunately the obstacles that are
placed in front of us are continuously
either shifting or growing and we're
challenged in securing that information
but I think with the right team and the
right ideas and the right people
involved we can get past that and work
towards building something that
hopefully I won't have to investigate in
the future that information you will be
able to see and out be outraged by
yourself so thank you for listening to
me I appreciate it if I have any can
answer your questions let me know
the secret six Stockholm we r we are we
are organizations called Project six and
we named it after six businessmen who

businessman wanted to end corruption in

city back which is essentially what we
want to do here we're not saying Al
Capone exists anymore but corruption
certainly does so it doesn't matter
where the corruption is we just want the
city to come back to where it should be
sure it's been an uphill battle I'll be

only been in effect for about three

start a new organization and take on a
significantly large investigation so
we're very proud of that that we were
able to finish this campaign finance
investigation we have a number of other

undertaking and we should start you
should start seeing the results of those
in the following months as legislative
inspector general we were successful in
ways that sometimes aren't quantifiable
but the fact that we still are talking
about ethics in chicago in a city where
it's been buried for so long is an
important step that simply is is
unquantifiable as legislative inspector
general i made we conducted a number
investigations including determining
that one-third of City Council we're
engaging in politics during city hours
wasting your taxpayer dollars by
engaging in political activities we've
identified alderman doing political

referred out to law enforcement agencies
for hopefully to see those come to
prosecution levels so we made a lot of
strides I won't deny there's still so

with you I'm not going to be able to do
it by myself and I and I don't mean to
say that as a cliche to any of you but
if someone was able to do it by
themselves they would have been able to
do it a long time ago there would be no
need for project six there would be no
need for the BGA or other organizations
this is a team effort and and the
biggest problem that we face here in
Chicago is apathy people simply just
don't care
much anymore they've accepted this
corruption as a way of life here in
Chicago that an alderman going to jail
or somebody asking you for a bribe or a
few dollars of a donation is the same as
it's cold here in winter it's just part
of your life in and that's not how it's
supposed to be and one of my biggest
goals as CEO project six is to get
people's mentality back to being Madigan
get angry just say enough is enough with
this is not how it's supposed to run you
know if you go to other cities i'm sure
some of you from other cities i heard
new york mentioned out there and and
people visiting from other places you'll
see the differences and how a government
is supposed to be run a municipal
government alderman here have your hand
have their hands and everything if you

on your house you go to your aldermen if
you want to build a business start a
business you go to your aldermen that
why it makes it makes absolutely no
sense and these are the kind of things
that we want Chicagoans to understand
that we have government agencies we have
city agencies that you should be working
with not going through a subjective
process involving one particular person
who may change every four years we so we
are privately funded so we take private
donations from anyone intent but we are
doing as much outreach as we can so we
are on Facebook we're on social media we
have our website up as I said we're just
trying to get this message across that
I'm out there as much as I can and
trying to fill a void because during
that time from when I stopped his
legislative inspector general and took
on this role at project six I spoke to a
great number of people who simply felt
that they didn't have any trust in
Chicago government anymore be it because
a police misconduct and the problems
that we face there be it because they
can't trust their aldermen or the mayor
or go to somebody in city government
without feeling that a deal has to be
made in some way that they felt that
there was a need for this and I've seen

and providing us with information so our
outreach continues on as much as we can
and hopefully being here this is another
opportunity for me to get the word out
that we are here and we're here to stay
project six isn't about me or it's not
about my staff it's about project six
it's a brand that we want to be here to
be taken as seriously as a credible
oversight agency here in Chicago that's
not going away and and we differentiate

to identify who's who and what's what
something I wasn't able to do is

was all these rules have changed now for

whether it was a lobbyist whether it was

whatever the reasoning was I did a

and I couldn't give you any of that

here we're get this to our communities

notta like the same old people who

it's not an insult to anyone I know and

this way of life and that's the attitude
that we need to change that they can be
better you know even though Chicago is a

in so many ways that doesn't mean it

advantage of that county and state if

is doing something illegal improper
engaging in waste fraud corruption on a

life in public service I I was an
investigator in New York of in the 90s
looking into police misconduct that's
where I started my career I went to law
school at night and then joined the
district attorney's office in New York
where I did that for eight years from
there I went to becoming Inspector
General in New York and I thought I was
going to take a break from public
service at that point and I said I'll go
to Chicago and I'll become a lawyer and
you know help people with immigration
and then I realized I just didn't like
asking people for money it was just not
something I wanted to do and the
legislative inspector general position
opened up and it was something right in
my wheelhouse and I was excited about it
because it was something that's never
been done in Chicago before I I was
naive at the time I'll be perfectly
honest with you I thought the fact that
Chicago created this legislative
inspector general position was that the
glass is half full that they were
finally a ready or wanting
put behind on their sordid history you
know Blagojevich had just gone to jail I
lost count of all the names of the
aldermen that I've come across in my
life that went to jail so I really
thought Chicago was ready to turn a
corner and I wanted to be a part of that
and unfortunately I learned fairly
quickly that that wasn't the case so the
way that ended to be perfectly honest
with you left a really bad taste in my
mouth and I think a lot of that comes
from the fact that I knew in my four
years as some of these problems really
could be fixed if we had serious people
fixing them you know I had a I had a

the support that we wanted to see that

unfortunately with the administrative

obstacle after obstacle we had to

you were under investigation I had to
tell you you're under ember
investigation within two weeks I could
hear the shredding going on from my
office you know this is information that
simply if you were my complainant I had
to tell the alderman your name and the
information about you the chilling
effects that those things have on
citizens here in Chicago is is above and

see if we can finally do something here
in chicago that's not been dumb and
whether i show up every week from i'm up

um i'll keep coming and talking to
